prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a couple living together where the author pays all the bills. The girlfriend only works part-time. The conflict arises from a single incident where the author had to ask her to pay for take-out because he forgot his wallet. She reacted negatively, and now he's considering making her pay some bills because of that. 

First, I need to consider both sides. The author might feel that the girlfriend's reaction was dismissive or entitled, especially since he covers everything. On the other hand, the girlfriend might feel like she's being treated unfairly because she can't afford to pay much given her part-time job.

In relationships, especially where one partner earns significantly more, splitting expenses can be a sensitive topic. The author is now questioning whether he should make her contribute more, even though she might not be able to afford a lot. The key here is whether the author's reaction is disproportionate to the incident. 

The incident was about a $40 take-out. The author points out that he covers all the rent and bills. The girlfriend's attitude was "ugly" and "put out," which the author finds offensive. But maybe the problem is that the author expected her to chip in more without prior agreement. If they didn't have an understanding about splitting expenses, then the girlfriend might not feel obligated. 

The author is now considering making her start paying some bills as a matter of principle. But is that fair? If the girlfriend can't afford it, forcing her might create more conflict. It's possible that the author is using this one incident as a catalyst to change the financial arrangement, which could be seen as the wrong approach because one incident might not justify a significant change in the relationship's dynamics. 

Also, the author's tone seems a bit entitled. He mentions that the girlfriend's part-time income probably has no expenses, implying that she should have money to spare. But part-time jobs don't usually provide enough to cover bills, especially if she has other costs like transportation, personal expenses, etc. 

So, the author might be in the wrong for expecting her to cover bills immediately after one incident, without considering her financial situation and without prior discussion. Relationships require communication and mutual understanding. Instead of reacting to a single event, he should talk about the financial responsibilities and agree on a fair arrangement. Making her pay bills as a punishment might be unfair and could lead to resentment. 

Therefore, the answer is A (the author is in the wrong).
